data.title: 24 Sextantis Star Facts
data.meta_description: 24 Sextantis is a white to yellow star in the constellation of Sextans. It can be seen in the night sky.
data.text:
In simplistic terms, all non-rogue stars, like planets, orbit around a central object, although that is actually not true. Where is the centre of the Solar System. For simplicity it's the central star, such as the Sun. In the case of a star, it's the galactic centre. The constellations we see today will be different than they were 50,000 years ago or 50,000 years from now.

Proper motion details the movements of these stars and is measured in milliarcseconds. 24 Sextantis is moving -34.92 ± 0.26 milliarcseconds/year towards the north and 66.21 ± 0.38 milliarcseconds/year east if we saw them in the horizon.

The radial velocity, the speed at which the 24 Sextantis is moving away from the Sun, is 7.09000 km/s with an error of about 0.23 km/s . When the value is negative, the star and the Sun are getting closer to one another; likewise, a positive number means that two stars are moving away. It's nothing to fear as the stars are so far apart they won't collide in our lifetime, if ever.

The table is scrollable if you can't see everything, just swipe the table to see the hidden information.
